instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RESET: What is PLT_RESET? PLT_RESET stands for platform reset. When this is asserted the machine will not POST. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I am with this board as not turning ON

Fan doesn't have any behavior

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8V
PP3V42 = 3.40v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = Tries to get to 5V and then drops to 0 and its a loop doing that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8V"
ALWAYS post EXACT voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (without battery)!!!

Check for pulse on all other coils; at same time with L7520.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Plug power cord appears for 1sec green light 

Turn off 

Then it turn orange

It had fan spin in a loop for a 30secs and stopped

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.58v
PP3V42 = 3.41v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = tries to go to 5V and back to 0V in loop 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  3.3v however after 5s with multimeter it goes to 0 and crazyly tries to go to 3.3 unstable and then gets stable

Replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>... Still same behavior with the cooler and lights changing.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.3 then tries to go to 3.3 and back to 0.3 in loop


L7520 = TRIES TO GO TO 5V AND THEN BACKS TO 0 IN A LOOP

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Sorry I can only measure one coil at time... Not sure how to measure other coils at the same time with L7520

However measurement below

L7320 = Goes to 1.6V and back to 0V in loop
L7310 = Goes to 1.6V and back to 0V in loop
L7630 = Goes to 1V and back to 0V in loop
L7430 = Goes to 1.2V and back to 0V in loop
L7520 = Is doesnt show 5V on the multimeter but it shows that tries to go high and then back to 0V
L7560 = 3.3v stable
L7130 = 8.58 stable
L3095 = 0V
L7701 = 0V

threads.message:
So you get pulse even on CPU core.
Check pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

What happens if try to start in SMC bypass mode?

Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>.

threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> traces and solders.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R1931</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.message:
<CHIP>U1930</CHIP>
PIN 2 = tries to go to 3.3 and then back to 0
PIN 1 = tries to go to 3.3 and then back to 0
PIN 6 = 3.3 stable as already mentioned 
<RESISTOR>R1931</RESISTOR> = 10K ohms = I guess its OK

If not, change <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>...

With pulse on pins 1 & 2, pin 4 MUST pulse too.
Check traces and solders of <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: What is the best way to check traces beyond visual inspection?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Through Buzer Mode

<RESISTOR>R1931</RESISTOR> communicates with <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>. However on the other side it goes directly to the CPU and I do not have any TP to check... It look likes it have a TP but it does NOT.

What to do now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and check if <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = Tries to go to 1V and then back to 0V in a loop

Put back <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and now its the same behavior as above

Tries to go to 1V and then back to 0V in a loop

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
PCH requires high level (1V) at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>, apart of 3V on pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
If you get pulse on these, <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> should pulse too.
If not, check all voltages from page 11 (pulse at least); be sure all series resistors and coils are good there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
out of nowhere  <SIGNAL>PLT_RSET_L</SIGNAL>   appears
Then I had fan spin...
Then I tried to assemble
But I do not have external image.

This Macbook is without Backlight Driver and I will first make sure its working externally before putting a new backlight driver

This board had a lot of corrosion from being an old board.

After the fan is working and I do not have image.... it gets to spin in a faster while after some 30secs I guess

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
If no LIO board, or trackpad connected, fan goes to max in 10-15s.

You should test the board alone on the desk for USB activity.
Also good to have a spare Air screen for test; I use broken one, to check backlight presence.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
You didn't mention anything about advanced corrosion when started the thread.
SMC should be reballed in such case.
Passing board trough ultrasonic bath may help; especially in case of accumulated crap under CPU, RAM, or other BGAs.
Be aware, incorrect UC may damage more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I already reballed the SMC and didn't work
I do not have ultrasonic cleaner for this board =( What did was cleaning some pads which I tought had a bit of corrosion. It's not that bad but its what I think is making the board sometimes have <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET</SIGNAL> and even sometimes making it have fan spin working and after following as you requests.

What do you mean by UC?

After all our chat what would you consider and look with more care? RAM doesnt look bad to be honest

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
An ultrasonic cleaner (UC) may help, but not sure 100%.

There should be corroded components/solders, or traces.
